Source: see p.104; but not really obligatory
p.79; 274, also in final position on clauses
comitative, see p. 136-137; coordination of NP, see p.206-208: zero, /o/ 'AND', /halali/ '3DU'.

Comment: p.19 argued fro ProtoTAP. AS: But it should be N here, since it is not synchronically present in Bunaq.
Yes in Corbett's sense of gender there is. But not if you mean a sex-based contrast of masculine- feminine.
p.98: only prox vs non-prox; there are other types of demonstratives/determiners

Feature: Is elevation morphologically marked in demonstratives?

Comment: It depends what you mean by classified. There is the animate-inanimate "gender" contrast marked on demonstratives

see p.117-118; p.197: Nouns are unmarked for number in Bunaq. Number may be optionally expressed through the use of items with quantificational meaning, specifying the amount of the
referent.

Feature: Is number marking prohibited on certain (types of) nouns?

Comment: There is an associative plural construction using the 3rd plural pronoun halaqi, see exs 59 and 60 on pg 196.
p.75: There is also a sizeable group of roots that may appear without derivation as either nouns or verbs (§3.4), p.89.

see p.89: a. verbs denoting an event/state and a noun denoting the associated instrument, result or patient of that event, and;
b. verbs denoting an event/state and a noun denoting that same event/state.
p.172-173ff: The Bunaq nominal classification system involves a two-way class distinction of ANIMATE versus INANIMATE noun class.

Feature: Is plant status a relevant category in any noun class/gender system?
Suggested standardised comments: Not mentioned, Nouns have semantic classification but the markers are not morphologically bound and are flexible, There is extensive classification but only to parts of the lexicon

Comment: p.173: Noun class is a covert property of Bunaq nouns. It is reflected on two agreement targets, prefixes on verbs (§10.1) and determiners (§7.1)

Source: p. 311 ff. There are restrictions on the post- and pre- posing of alienable possessor phrases headed by gie depending on the meaning they carry.

Comment: p.83: There is no distinct adjective class in Bunaq. […] In Bunaq all verbs can occur attributively. That is, regardless of whether a verb is stative or active, monovalent or bivalent, it can occur modifying the head of an NP.

Source: p. 29 no morphological case in Bunaq

Comment:
p.105: the oblique (locational and temporal) postposition no ‘OBL’ (and its dialectal variant ni ‘OBL’), the locational
postposition gene ‘LOC’ and the similative postposition goet ‘LIKE’.
In verbal postpositions, p.417
p.29: Bunaq TAM marking is by serial verbs or postverbal free morphemes, similar to the Papuan type.

Feature: Are there multiple past or future tenses, distinguishing distance from Time of Reference, marked on the verb?

Comment: p.358: In the corpus, there are seven monovalent verbs which have agreement prefixes coindexing their S argument. The S arguments of prefixing monovalent verbs are patientive, being low in properties such as control and volition

p.338: Prefixes on bivalent verbs index the P argument, and never the A. Bivalent verbs divide into the four classes seen above with the division made chiefly according to the prototypical ANIMACY of the P argument and the manner in which it is coindexed on the verb.

Are variations in marking strategies of core participants based on person distinctions?

Comment: by means of erstwhile SVC > verbal postposition /h-ege/ '3sg-give', see p. 435
by means of verbal postposition /dele/, p.421
referred to as 'labile verbs'
described as post-verbal predicate aspectual particles, p.499
In trivalent clauses, the theme frequently occurs post-predicate, p.126
p.137: Clauses are negated by means of the clausal negator niq ‘NEG’ following the predicate. Niq ‘NEG’ is used to negate a clause irrespective of the type of predicate
p.141: negative imperatives are  encoded with the prohibitive modality adverb, hani ‘PROH’
p.137: Niq ‘NEG’ is used to negate a clause irrespective of the type of predicate
By prefixing on some verb classes, see p.358

By absence of verbal prefixation and expression by free pronouns, see p.339 for Class I bivalent verbs, and p. 357: There are 502 monovalent verbs in the corpus. Each subcategorises for only an S argument (see §10.6 on verbs taking an S and an OBL) and take no agreement prefix.
p.384 /dV-/ reflexives are passive-like, i.e. middle verbs
sasi 'say, speak, tell' is not used in such contexts in the examples
p.446; and by means of /h-ini/ '3sg-caus', see p. 367

p.361: Note that g-ini ‘3AN-CAUS’ in (41d) is a straightforward causative with the verb topol ‘fall’ and not introducing a supposition. Answer was Y, but AS: I am not sure that Y is the right answer here. I think the meaning of -ini to denote an attributed quotation is an extension of the indirect causation denoted by -ini and not the other way round. Etymologically, -ini is a verb 'give' and not 'say'.
Yes! At least in my understanding of the definition. See, for instance, ex 30 pg 251, ex 37 pg 255.
Numerals reduplicate, see pg 99.

p.178: In the ANIMATE class are the nouns referring to corn, potato and pumpkin, foods which are at the centre of the diets of the Bunaq people and are the focus of agricultural production. By contrast, the crops of the INANIMATE noun class items, such as taro and rice, are on the whole much less significant in the livelihoods of the Bunaq.

Comment: p.193: The head of a restrictive RC occurs at the front of the RC marked with the restrictive focus particle na ‘FOC’ (§3.5.7.2). As with non-restrictive RCs, the head is gapped, that is, is missing from inside the RC itself.

Comment: Terms for males of the ego’s parent’s generation show a “simple bifurcate merging pattern”: males of the parental generation on the ego’s father’s family are referred to as “father”, while males of the parental generation on the ego’s mother’s family have a distinct term, baba.
